instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2914: What is 820-2914? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_PWR_SW: What is PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_PWR_SW? PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_PWR_SW is a line after the inductor in the DC to DC boost circuit for backlight that connects to the LED driver’s switch(SW) pin where it is switched to ground rapidly in order to create the boosted voltage for the backlight circuit. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.BKL_FB: What is BKL_FB? This is backlight feedback. It goes from the output of the backlight circuit back to the LED driver, so it can see what it is doing. If this line is broken or corroded, the boost circuit will not boost PPBUS_G3H to a higher voltage for backlight, and backlight voltage output will be the same as the PPBUS_G3H input. This trace/via is usually the first to corrode since it is the highest voltage in the system..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message:
got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no data or bklt,  chimes. shows dark screen under flashlight.  lvds connector is good. getting power from the  l9000.   Had liquid damage. point in the right direction? 
Thanks 
Nate

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message:
If L9000 has 3V something must happen to the LCD when you turn it on. Hold flashlight to the back of the Apple logo and then turn machine on.
What is voltage on backlight bus to connector?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message:
When i turn it on with the light of course from the back side of the apple logo. when i turn it on the screen reacts and makes the light become hard to see through the glass. if i turn it off i can see my light very well. this is the same thing im getting with the other board.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_PWR_SW</SIGNAL> im getting (-.08)v to (-1.5)v @ <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> im getting (.2)v

also im getting solid 3.4v on the <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> present? Fuse good? Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKL</SIGNAL> with LCD plugged in?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.2v so yes.

fuse was bad replaced it but no change 

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKL</SIGNAL> = 92.2 ohms to gnd on pin 40-38.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: So you replace the fuse while there is a semi short on the backlight bus? Resistance should be 150K+. Bad connector/lcd cable and dead fuse again probably.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message:
yeah okay i didnt realize that! haha lack there of knowledge = more work. :o   

 replaced the lvds connector and tried it on a second tested working screen and still the same.  getting 90 ohms on the <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0</SIGNAL>. also double checked the fuse and it was still good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: 90 Ohm is coming from somewhere. Remove all components on the rails till the short is gone. Could also be in the board, usually at the LCD connector where it burns.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: okay.  i removed <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> and i was getting 120 ohms.  like you said we need 150+ so i removed the xwd1150 and i got 250-350 ohms before it goes to saying 0 ohms.  but if i replace these parts it goes back to 90 ohms so the short is in the line? what do i need to look for or do?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: I have no idea what you are doing. Remove <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> and on pin 2 you should get 100K+. If lower than that there is a short on that rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: I had this board sitting to the side for a wile, just got back to it.  if i remove <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> i get 122k ohm on pin 2.  what would i need to do to fix this semi short? sorry i dont know more to fix this entirely on my own, shorts really get me.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: With <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> removed what is resistance to GND on both pins? Check <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> on diode mode for short?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message:
343.9k ohms to ground on pin 1 
122.2k ohms to gnd on pin 2
my meter does not have the right diode test mode its instead merged with the ohm reading, so im not sure how accurate it will be, but im getting 0.943k ohms one way and OL the other way.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: In post #7 you say 90 Ohm, in #9 you are telling me 120 Ohm. I have no idea what you are doing.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: Yes in post # 7 i was testing with the <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> connected.  in post #9 i was testing without the <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: Should in no way cause 90 or 120 Ohm, still have no idea what you are doing.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: if i remove <RESISTOR>R9709</RESISTOR> or <RESISTOR>R9708</RESISTOR> the short goes away and i get 150k+ ohms at <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>.  if i replace them there is no change and i did check the parts and i was getting proper ohms from them.  if i pull the <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> the short is still there so the problem is not in the <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>.  where the heck could this short be coming from if it goes away on the <SIGNAL>BKL_FB</SIGNAL> by removing 9709 or 9708.  either one removed eliminated the short.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no data or bklt
threads.message: This can only happen if <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> is shorted.
